title: Whitehaven sticks to its guns on coal demand
text:
ASX-listed miner Whitehaven Coal passed its remuneration report without a murmur at its annual general meeting held at The Mint on Sydney's Macquarie Street on Thursday.

Just iver 98 per cent of votes were in favour, with just 1.6 per cent against.

However, a resolution to re-elect director John Conde was slightly more controversial, with 7.41 per cent of votes cast against the motion and 92.59 per cent for. The resolution was carried.

The company reported a net profit after tax of $564.9 million for the financial year to June 30.

Whitehaven chief executive Paul Flynn stuck to his core message throughout the meeting, and argued that while demand for thermal coal is increasing in South East Asia, the supply of the product will remain relatively "flat".

This thesis forms the centre of the miner's contention that their business will remain "sustainable" until 2040 under "all three energy scenarios" used by the International Energy Agency.
description: Management also doubled down on their core business thesis that thermal coal has a future in South East Asia, despite its stock being down 3 per cent from last year.
